description: Borrowed from Italian mantelletta, from mantello (“cloak, mantle”) + -etta (from -etto (“suffix forming a diminutive of a noun”)), probably from Late Latin mantelletum (“a short, sleeveless cape or cloak; a mantlet”). Doublet of mantlet.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A sleeveless, knee-length vestment open at the front which is worn by Roman Catholic prelates.
